Department of Computing, Imperial College London, London, UK
Jose Pablo Folch
Department of Mathematics, Imperial College London, London, UK
Ruby Sedgwick
Departments of Materials, Bioengineering, and Computing, Imperial College London, London, UK

Abstract
Monitoring air pollution is crucial for the overall health of the population. Unfortunately, devices that measure air quality can be expensive, and many cities in low- and middle-income countries rely on a limited number of them. This paper investigates the use of Gaussian Processes for nowcasting air pollution in areas without sensors and forecasting air pollution at sensor locations. We focus on Kampala, Uganda, using data from AirQo's network of sensors. We demonstrate the benefits of removing outliers, compare different kernel functions and additional inputs, and compare two sparse approximations to handle large amounts of temporal data.

1 Introduction
The World Health Organization recognizes air quality as the single biggest environmental threat to human health, estimated to cause 7 million deaths annually. Air pollution is predicted to worsen with climate change. Particulate matter with a diameter of 2.5 micrometers or less (PM2.5) has been linked to increased mortality from all causes, cardiovascular disease, respiratory disease, and lung cancer. PM2.5 has also been found to have short-term global heating effects. Monitoring PM2.5 levels in cities is essential, but air pollution sensors are often too expensive. AirQo, a research group based in Uganda, aims to empower communities across Africa with information about air quality to increase awareness and encourage citizens to take action against pollution. To address the lack of air quality information in sub-Saharan Africa, AirQo has deployed a sparse network of low-cost air quality monitors in multiple cities.

We aim to accurately predict PM2.5 levels in Kampala using data from AirQo's network of air quality sensors. Due to the sparse placement of sensors, we require a predictive model that is data-efficient and provides a measure of uncertainty, which is useful for decision-making. Gaussian processes (GPs) meet these criteria, so we investigate their use for air pollution prediction, comparing the performance of various kernels, input factors, and sparse approximations to find the best GP model for nowcasting and forecasting.

Data and code are available through the link in Appendix B.

2 Background and Related Work
2.1 Gaussian Processes
A Gaussian Process is a stochastic process such that for any number of input points, the function values follow a multivariate Gaussian distribution. The distribution is defined by a mean function and a positive definite covariance function or kernel. When modeling an unknown function, it is common to assume data of the form y = f(x) + σϵ, where σ > 0, and ϵ is noise modeled using a standard Gaussian distribution. GP regression assumes the noise model and puts a GP prior on the unknown function. The posterior of the function given a dataset can be calculated analytically.

2.2 Kernel Functions
The kernel function specifies the covariance of the Gaussian distribution and defines the class of functions it can learn. We focus on the squared exponential and periodic kernels. The squared exponential kernel assigns similarity to inputs that are close together, while the periodic kernel assigns similarity between inputs that are in similar parts of the period. We can build a kernel from the product or sum of kernel functions, allowing for flexible combinations of different kernels.

2.3 Scalability of Gaussian Processes
Computing a GP posterior requires inverting a matrix, which typically incurs a cubic cost in the number of training data points.
